column1: Newark lies in the transition between a humid subtropical and humid continental climate (Köppen Cfa/Dfa)

column6: though variations in weather patterns may bring sparse snowfall in some years and several major nor'easters in others
column7: with the heaviest 24-hour fall of 25.9 inches (66 cm) occurring on December 26
column8: 1947. Spring and autumn in the area are generally unstable yet mild. The July daily mean is 77.4 °F (25.2 °C)
column9: and highs exceed 90 °F (32 °C) on an average 27 days per year
column10: not factoring in the often higher heat index. Precipitation is evenly distributed throughout the year with the summer months being the wettest and fall months being the driest.

The Presbyterian community is dominated by the Presbyterian Church (USA) and Presbyterian Church in America. The Pentecostal community is dominated by the Church of God in Christ and Assemblies of God USA.0.9% of Christians in the city and nearby suburbs identify as Anglican or Episcopalian. The remainder identified with Continuing Anglican or Evangelical Episcopal bodies including the Reformed Episcopal Church and Anglican Church in North America. ACNA and REC-affiliated churches form the Diocese of the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic.

column2: the Bell System under ownership of American Telephone and Telegraph Company (AT&T) tested newly developed panel switching technology in Newark when they cutover the telephone exchanges Mulberry and Waverly to semi-mechanical operation on January 16 and June 12
column3: respectively. The Panel system was the Bell System solution to the big city problem
column4: where an exchange had to serve large numbers of subscribers on both manual as well as automatically switched central offices
column5: without negatively impacting established user convenience and reliability. As originally introduced in these exchanges
column6: subscribers' telephones had no dials and customers continued to make calls by asking an operator to ring their called party
column7: at which point the operator keyed the telephone number into the panel equipment
column8: instead of making cord connections manually.Most Panel installations across the country were replaced by modern systems during the 1970s and the last Panel switch was decommissioned in the BIgelow central office in Newark in 1983.

column1: Newark has been marred with political corruption throughout the years. Five of the previous seven mayors of Newark have been indicted on criminal charges
column2: including the three mayors before Cory Booker: Hugh Addonizio
column3: Kenneth Gibson and Sharpe James. As reported by Newsweek: "... every mayor since 1962 (except one
column4: Cory Booker) has been indicted for crimes committed while in office".Addonizio was mayor of Newark from 1962 to 1970. A son of Italian immigrants
column5: a tailor and World War II veteran
column6: he ran on a reform platform
column7: defeating the incumbent
column8: Leo Carlin
column9: whom
column11: Addonizio characterized as corrupt and a part of the political machine of the era. In December 1969
column12: Addonizio and nine present or former officials of the municipal administration in Newark were indicted by a Federal grand jury; five other persons were also indicted. In July 1970
column13: the former mayor
column15: were found guilty by a Federal jury on 64 counts each
column16: one of conspiracy and 63 of extortion. In September 1970
column17: Addonizio was sentenced to ten years in federal prison and fined $25
column18: 000 by Federal Judge George Herbert Barlow for his role in a plot that involved the extortion of $1.5 million in kickbacks
column19: a crime that the judge said "tore at the very heart of our civilized society and our form of representative government".His successor was Kenneth Gibson
column20: the city's first African American mayor
column21: elected in 1970. He pleaded guilty to federal tax evasion in 2002 as part of a plea agreement on fraud and bribery charges. During his tenure as mayor in 1980
column22: Gibson was tried and acquitted of giving out no-show jobs by an Essex County jury.Sharpe James
column23: who defeated Gibson in 1986 and declined to run for a sixth term in 2006
column24: was indicted on 33 counts of conspiracy
column26: and wire fraud by a federal grand jury sitting in Newark. The grand jury charged James with spending $58
column27: 000 on city-owned credit cards for personal gain and orchestrating a scheme to sell city-owned land at below-market prices to his companion
column28: who immediately re-sold the land to developers and gained a profit of over $500
column29: 000. James pleaded not guilty on 25 counts at his initial court appearance on July 12
column32: James was found guilty for his role in the conspiring to rig land sales at nine city-owned properties for personal gain. The former mayor was sentenced to serve up to 27 months in prison

column1: University Hospital EMS (UH-EMS) operates the EMS system for the city. The department operates a fleet of six BLS units staffed with two EMTs 24/7
column2: supplemented by four 12-hour "power" units (operated during peak demand time hours)
column3: five ALS units staffed with two paramedics (one of which is stationed at Newark International Airport and covers the airport and Port Newark-Elizabeth
column4: and frequently responds into the City of Elizabeth)
column5: and a critical care unit staffed by a paramedic and an RN. With distinction they also staff the only hospital based heavy rescue truck in the country
column6: known as University EMS Rescue 1. The EMS system is the busiest system per unit in the nation. On average
column7: a BLS unit may be sent to 20–25 dispatches in a 12-hour shift. They also provide the medical staffing for Northstar and Southstar
column8: which are the two NJ State Police medevac helicopters
column9: staffing one flight nurse and a flight medic around the clock. The EMS system in Newark handles upwards of 125
column10: 000 requests for service annually. The Ironbound Volunteer Ambulance Squad helps by handling BLS calls in the East Ward when members are on duty and has been in operation since 1969.

column26: and reserve units. The NFD responds to approximately 45

column1: The Newark Police Department is a city-operated law enforcement agency. As of January 2014

column3: 006 officers in its ranks. The director of Public Safety is Anthony J. Ambrose.

column2: Money magazine ranked Newark "The Most Dangerous City in the Nation." By 2007
column3: the city recorded a total of 99 homicides for the year
column4: representing a significant drop from the record of 161 murders set in 1981. The number of murders in 2008 dropped to 65
column5: a decline of 30% from the previous year and the lowest in the city since 2002 when there were also 65 murders.In 2010
column6: Newark recorded 90 homicides. March 2010 was the first calendar month since 1966 in which the city did not record a homicide. Overall
column7: there was a 6% increase in crime numbers over the previous year
column8: including a rise in carjackings for the third straight year
column9: with the 337 incidents raising concerns that the city was returning to its status as the "car theft capital of the world". Along with the increase in crime
column10: the Newark Police Department increased its recovery of illegally owned guns in 2011 to 696
column11: up from 278 in 2010. The Federal Bureau of Investigation recorded 94 homicides in 2011 and 95 in 2012. In 2012 CNNMoney ranked Newark as the 6th most dangerous city in the United States
column12: based on numbers by FBI Crime in the United States 2011 report. The city had 10 murders in 10 days during the period ending September 6
column14: a statistic largely attributed to the reduction of the police force. In 2013 Newark recorded 111 homicides
column15: the first year ending in triple digits in seven years and the highest tally since 1990
column16: accounting for 27% of all murders statewide. In 2014
column17: the total number of homicides in Newark was 93
column18: while Essex County as a whole had 117 murders. The Star-Ledger reported that there were 105 homicides in the city in 2015. The city had 72 homicides in 2017
column19: a statistic described as a "historic low"
column20: and a sharp drop from the 96 murders recorded in the city in 2016. The Newark Police reported 69 homicides for 2018. As of August 13
column22: after of period of 50 consecutive days without a homicide
column23: a total of 34 had been recorded.

column2: lead concentrations in water accumulated for several years in the 2010s as a result of inaccurate testing and poor leadership. While not at the same scale as the case of Flint
column3: Michigan
column4: it was said that Newark's problem came from a similar ignorance of officials who the city relied on to ensure their clean water. The decrease in the quality of the water was due to several factors that were all somewhat interconnected. Lead service pipes that carry water were installed in Newark.When this was realized
column5: the city had CDM Smith
column6: a construction company that specializes in water systems
column7: conduct a study to determine whether or not the water quality was safe enough to drink. The results revealed that the water was in fact safe to drink
column8: but the results were severely skewed. This is because the city receives water from two water supplies: the Pequannock Treatment Plant and the Wanaque Treatment Plant. In some sampling rounds
column9: only areas served by Pequannock were sampled
column11: only areas served by Wanaque were sampled
column12: and each had different contaminant control systems in place that varied in their effectiveness. The Pequannock supply uses pH adjustments and silica for its corrosion control method
column13: which worked for two decades before losing its effectiveness in 2016
column14: while the Wanaque supply uses orthophosphate
column15: a much more effective precaution.In addition to this
column16: the EPA requires that samples of drinking water be taken after no one has turned on a faucet for at least eight hours. Therefore
column17: if high levels of lead do not show up in that initial sample
column18: no further samples are required. This sample only represents the water closest to the faucet
column19: that has not been stagnant in lead service lines
column20: whereas the stagnant water in the lead piping may not be drawn until much later.Top officials in Newark denied that their water system had a widespread lead problem
column21: declaring on their website that the water was absolutely safe to drink. Even after municipal water tests revealed the severity of the problem Mayor Ras Baraka mailed a brochure to the cities residents that the water meets all federal standards. Although the city called an emergency declaration to allow them to purchase and distribute water filters for faucets but many of these were faulty. The city has received three noncompliance notices for exceeding lead levels since 2017 and continues to fight its lead problem.

column1: Newark is a hub of air
column2: road
column3: rail
column4: and ship traffic
column5: making it a significant gateway into the New York metropolitan area and the mid-Atlantic United States.Newark Liberty International Airport is the second-busiest airport in the New York metro area and the 15th-busiest in the United States (in terms of passenger traffic). Newark Airport was the New York City area's first commercial airport
column6: opened in 1928 on land reclaimed by the Port Authority.Port Newark
column7: on Newark Bay
column8: is the 15th-busiest port in the world and the largest container port on the East Coast of the United States. In 2003
column9: the port moved over $100 billion in goods.

column2: stretching 102 miles (164 km) to Newark from Phillipsburg on the Delaware River
column3: was completed in 1831 and allowed coal and other industrial and agricultural products from Pennsylvania to be transported cheaply and efficiently to the New York metropolitan area. The canal's completion led to increased settlement in Newark
column4: vastly increasing the population for years to come. After the canal was decommissioned
column5: its right of way was converted into the Newark City Subway
column6: now known as the Newark Light Rail. Many of the subway stations still portray the canal in its original state
column7: in the form of mosaic works.As the city became increasingly congested further means of transportation were sought
column8: eventually leading to horse-drawn trolleys. These
column9: in turn
column10: were replaced by electric trolleys that traveled down the main streets of downtown Newark
column11: including Broad Street
column12: and up Market Street near the courthouse. The trolley cars did not last long as the personal motor vehicle quickly gained popularity and slowly made the trolley system seem like a burden.

column2: the city had a total of 368.21 miles (592.58 km) of roadways
column3: of which 318.77 miles (513.01 km) were maintained by the municipality
column4: 17.61 miles (28.34 km) by Essex County
column5: 22.66 miles (36.47 km) by the New Jersey Department of Transportation and 9.17 miles (14.76 km) by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.

column1: Newark is served by numerous highways including the New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95)
column2: Interstate 280
column3: Interstate 78
column4: the Garden State Parkway
column5: U.S. Route 1/9
column6: U.S. Route 22
column7: and Route 21. Newark is connected to the Holland Tunnel and Lower Manhattan by the Pulaski Skyway
column8: spanning both the Passaic and Hackensack Rivers
column9: which was first constructed in 1938 and recently underwent a $900 million renovation project.Local streets in Newark conform to a quasi-grid form
column10: with major streets radiating outward (like spokes on a wheel) from the downtown area. Some major roads in the city are named after the towns to which they lead
column11: including South Orange Avenue
column12: Springfield Avenue
column13: and Bloomfield Avenue
column15: which had been renamed from Belleville Avenue.In a city extensively served by mass transit
column16: 44.2% of Newark residents did not have a car as of the 2000 Census
column17: ranked second in the U.S. to New York City in the proportion of households without an automobile among cities with more than 250
column18: 000 people. According to the 2016 American Community Survey
column19: the number of households without an automobile has decreased to 39.2%. The same year
column20: the average Newark household owned .89 cars compared to a national average of 1.8 cars per household.

column2: situated just east of downtown
column3: is the city's major train station. It is served by the interurban PATH train (which links Newark 24/7 to Jersey City and Manhattan)
column4: three NJ Transit (NJT) commuter rail lines
column5: and Amtrak intercity rail service. It was designed by McKim
column6: Mead & White and completed in 1935. One mile north
column7: the Newark Broad Street Station is served by two NJT commuter rail lines. The two train stations are linked by the Newark Light Rail system
column8: which also provides services from Newark Penn Station to Newark's northern communities and into the neighboring towns of Belleville and Bloomfield. Built in the bed of the Morris Canal
column9: the light rail cars run underground in Newark's downtown area. The city's third train station
column11: connects the Northeast Corridor to the airport via AirTrain Newark.

column1: Bus service in Newark is provided by NJ Transit
column2: CoachUSA contract operators and DeCamp in North Newark. Newark is served by  NJ Transit bus routes 1
column39: and 108. The 107 and 108 routes run to New York City. Bus route 308 is an express bus route to Six Flags Great Adventure from Newark Penn Station while 319 is an express service to Atlantic City.The go bus 25 and go bus 28 are bus rapid transit lines through the city to Irvington
column40: Bloomfield and Newark Liberty International Airport.

column1: According to the 2016 American Community Survey
column2: 53.7% of working city of Newark residents commuted by driving alone
column3: 9.3% carpooled
column4: 27.3% used public transportation
column5: and 6.5% walked. About 5% used all other forms of transportation
column6: including taxicab
column7: motorcycle
column8: and bicycle. About 5.7% of working Newark residents worked at home.

column1: Newark is home to five hospitals. University Hospital
column2: an independent institution that is a teaching hospital of Rutgers Biomedical and Health Sciences
column3: has been the busiest Level I trauma center in the state. Newark Beth Israel Medical Center is the largest hospital in the city and is a part of Barnabas Health
column4: the state's largest system of hospital and health care facilities. Beth Israel is also one of the oldest hospitals in the city
column5: dating back to 1901. This 669-bed regional facility is also home to the Children's Hospital of New Jersey. Catholic Health East operates Saint Michael's Medical Center. Columbus Hospital LTACH is a longterm acute care hospital designed to focus on patients with serious and complex medical conditions that require intense specialized treatment for an extended period of recovery time. Hospitals which have been closed in recent years include the Saint James Hospital
column6: Mount Carmel Guild Hospital and the United Hospitals Medical Center.In 2016
column7: annual testing of the water in Newark's public schools revealed elevated lead levels; more than 30 schools shut off their water fountains and turned to bottled water. In August 2019 the crisis over lead contamination in drinking water resurfaced because of new warnings from federal environmental officials. It is believed that the contamination was caused by aging lead pipes and changes in the water supply that makes the water more corrosive
column8: causing lead from the pipes to be spread to the water inside. In August 2019
column9: New Jersey began supplying water bottles to Newark residents in certain designated neighborhoods. On August 26
column11: Newark officials announced a $120 million plan to expedite replacing the city's lead service lines in under three years. The 29
column12: 000 families affected by the contaminated water were provided with filters and bottled water. After testing in September
column13: it was found that the filters were successful in 97% of homes tested
column14: though bottled water would still be made available to those who request it. Long term-plans include the replacement of lead service lines from the water supply to homes.

column1: The Consulate-General of Ecuador in New Jersey is at 400 Market Street. The Consulate-General of Portugal in Newark is at the main floor of the Newark Legal Center at One Riverfront Plaza. The Consulate-General of Colombia is at 550 Broad Street. The Vice Consulate of Italy was at 1 Gateway Center
column2: until it was closed in 2014 for economic reasons.Pope John Paul II visited the city in 1995
column3: at which time he elevated the city's cathedral to a basilica to become the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart. In 2011
